quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Regardless of whether or not you're hiring, you should always be keeping a pulse on the market. That is the most important thing.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A core operating principle: treat talent market awareness as an always-on practice, not something you do only when you have an open role.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Like, you never want to put yourself in a position where you have no idea what good looks like, whether that's from a company standpoint or from a candidate standpoint.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A benchmarking mental model for both hiring managers and candidates: continuously calibrate your definition of “good” to avoid blind spots.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Oftentimes, I encourage founders to simply chat with what good looks like and get a really good sense of what benchmark candidate profiles could be, and who knows where that person will be in a year or what have you, but staying really, really close to really great people and using them from an advising capacity or getting them ingrained in some type of involvement in the product prior to actually having that specific need, I think, is really important.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A proactive recruiting strategy: build relationships early and involve top talent before you have a formal opening to improve future hiring outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: She's placed over 80 senior product leaders across tech companies and has worked with some of the biggest companies out there.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete credibility/data point that signals the guest’s depth of experience in senior product hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Miro
quotes.text: Retool allows teams as small as just one person to build a suite of custom internal apps in a fraction of the time that you think it takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a leverage point for practitioners: small teams can rapidly build internal tools without needing large engineering investment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Miro
quotes.text: The productivity gains of custom apps is now within reach, not just for large enterprises, but for small teams as well.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A reframing that internal-tool ROI isn’t only an enterprise advantage—small teams can capture it too.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Miro
quotes.text: Snowflake saves about 26 hours a week of manual spreadsheet work with custom internal apps built on Retool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete data point you can use to justify internal tooling investment by translating it into time saved.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Miro
quotes.text: Amazon uses Retool to handle GDPR requests.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific example showing internal tools can support high-stakes operational/compliance workflows, not just dashboards.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Miro
quotes.text: With Miro, you can build out your product strategy by brainstorming sticky notes, comments, live reactions, voting tools, even a timer to keep your team on track.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable methodology for running structured, collaborative strategy sessions with built-in facilitation mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Lauren’s career path into executive search
quotes.text: I originally thought that I wanted to be on the news and quickly realized I didn't necessarily want to be the face of sadness. There's a ton of that happening in the world.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of career fit—recognizing misalignment early and pivoting based on the day-to-day emotional reality of the work.

quotes.topic_title: Lauren’s career path into executive search
quotes.text: So, made a pivot pretty early on and thought, where could I use the communication skills that I've been working so hard on and do something that's impactful in a big way, but maybe just with a little bit of a different angle?
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A practical career decision framework: identify transferable skills, define desired impact, and change the “angle” rather than starting over.

quotes.topic_title: Lauren’s career path into executive search
quotes.text: I had applied to all of these different companies like Twitter and Snap and Pinterest, hadn't heard back from any of them, was a name in the resumes, and thought, well, how cool would it be if I could work with all of them and have an opportunity to play a part from a different lens?
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Turns rejection into strategy—choosing a role (exec search) that provides leverage and access across many top companies at once.

quotes.topic_title: Lauren’s career path into executive search
quotes.text: So I was the first recruiting hire over there, built out the talent function in its entirety.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A concrete example of taking an operator role to gain end-to-end ownership and systems-building experience in recruiting.

quotes.topic_title: Lauren’s career path into executive search
quotes.text: I definitely think there was a part of me that I loved the operating experience, learned a ton, worked side by side some amazing people, but was really missing working with founders, and lots of them, and keeping a pulse on the market.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Highlights a key tradeoff practitioners can use to choose between in-house vs. agency/VC recruiting: depth with one team vs. breadth with many founders and market visibility.

quotes.topic_title: Why top recruiters are moving to VC
quotes.text: It's definitely not a comp thing. I'll say that.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that top recruiters move to VC primarily for higher pay.

quotes.topic_title: Why top recruiters are moving to VC
quotes.text: Search is incredibly volatile, and you have to hustle so hard, and as soon as you have three wins, you've got four more things to execute on.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Explains the operational reality of agency recruiting as a constant, compounding workload—useful for setting expectations and designing sustainable processes.

quotes.topic_title: Why top recruiters are moving to VC
quotes.text: you really do have to chase business and you can't be selective about what you take on, so you could be pitching things that maybe you don't necessarily believe in in its entirety or what have you.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Highlights a practical tradeoff in down markets: business development pressure can force misalignment with the work you accept.

quotes.topic_title: Why top recruiters are moving to VC
quotes.text: It's really scary to take a bet on one single company right now and know what it's going to look like six months from now.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Captures the risk calculus pushing talent leaders away from in-house roles toward portfolio-based environments like VC.

quotes.topic_title: Common founder mistake: chasing big-name CPOs
quotes.text: I think especially for founders that haven't hired for this caliber of talent in the past, it's really easy to be distracted by shiny objects and look at huge names.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Highlights a common early-stage hiring trap: optimizing for brand-name pedigree instead of fit for the stage and role.

quotes.topic_title: Common founder mistake: chasing big-name CPOs
quotes.text: But the fact of the matter is, oftentimes those individuals are pretty far from the work and have a great team of executors that they've put into place that are actually the ones that are in the weeds.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Explains why big-company CPOs can underperform in startups: their recent success may rely on layers of execution they won’t have early on.

quotes.topic_title: Common founder mistake: chasing big-name CPOs
quotes.text: So, I think looking for someone that's a little closer to the work, maybe someone that can step up into that type of role and do so in a way where some days they might actually be operating like a PM and then other days they might be able to build from a leadership perspective, that's more of the DNA that people should be targeting.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Gives a practical hiring profile for early-stage product leaders: a hybrid operator-leader who can toggle between IC execution and leadership building.

quotes.topic_title: Common founder mistake: chasing big-name CPOs
quotes.text: Yeah. I would say the general advice is who is going to be best for this specific role at this specific time, not necessarily who is the best talent in the world or in the market. Those are two very, very different questions to ask.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Provides a simple decision framework: evaluate candidates by role-and-stage fit rather than absolute “best talent” status.

quotes.topic_title: Common founder mistake: chasing big-name CPOs
quotes.text: Just because this is the best talent, that doesn't necessarily mean they are the best talent for this role today.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb that reinforces stage-appropriate hiring over prestige-driven selection.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the role: mandate, success, and org design
quotes.text: So I think it's trying to work a little bit backwards and think about, what is the actual outcome that we are trying to solve for with this hire? Or are we just hiring a head of product because we feel like we need to hire a head of product?
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A practical “work backwards from outcomes” test to avoid role-driven hiring that isn’t tied to a real business need.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the role: mandate, success, and org design
quotes.text: That's so often what I see is the board's telling me we need to hire a head of product and I don't necessarily think that we do, or I'm not exactly sure what we need in this role. And so whenever you're starting a search in that regard, it's kind of doomed from inception, so you need to get incredibly granular on the front end around, what is this person going to be coming in to do? What's their mandate?
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that “board-driven” hiring without clarity on mandate sets the search up to fail, and a prescription to get granular early.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the role: mandate, success, and org design
quotes.text: And if we think about someone that's just absolutely hitting it out of the park and crushing it, what does that look like?
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A simple success-definition prompt that forces concrete expectations before interviewing candidates.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the role: mandate, success, and org design
quotes.text: Like the 90 day plan is something that's overused but so necessary, and that's just the tip of the iceberg.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Reframes the common “90-day plan” as necessary but insufficient—pushing leaders to define longer-horizon success too.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the role: mandate, success, and org design
quotes.text: So that component and then, okay, a year from now, what should this person be doing? Two years from now? Do we want them to grow up into a CPO role? Do we think about that in a different way?
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A concrete time-horizon framework (90 days/1 year/2 years) to align the hire with org evolution and career path expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Product leader archetypes and avoiding unicorn roles
quotes.text: Yeah, there's platform product leaders or folks that are kind of more indexed on the infrastructure components. There's folks that are typically focused on core product, or consumer product if it's on the consumer side of things. And then you'll have folks that are really indexed and that can include UX individuals, design folks. And then there's also typically specialists, so individuals that are really hyper-focused on growth or monetization or what have you. Those are the three buckets that I would say I see most often.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A practical archetype framework for quickly bucketing the kind of product leader you actually need.

quotes.topic_title: Product leader archetypes and avoiding unicorn roles
quotes.text: Well, it's kind of twofold. I think sometimes people just bring in a head of product to do everything, so that's probably not the best way to go about things. I think that ends up being a unicorn, which you hear often in the search world, and it becomes really difficult to hone in on what good looks like.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Warns against “unicorn” hiring and highlights how it blurs evaluation criteria for success.

quotes.topic_title: Product leader archetypes and avoiding unicorn roles
quotes.text: And so I think again, it just comes back to having a clear org chart on the front end and determining, are we hiring someone specifically to build out our walled garden ads approach, or are we hiring someone to run product marketing, or are we hiring someone to help from a product perspective to build a better core user experience? Those are all very, very, very different roles, and if you bring in one person to try and do it all, the facts of the matter is, they're going to have to bring in some key lieutenants to help them, so is that something you want to do or are you more focused on bringing in someone imminently to help on the ad side of things, and then we can find that head of product to help them out down the road?
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A concrete method for scoping the role by mapping it to an org chart and specific near-term outcomes rather than a generic leadership title.

quotes.topic_title: Product leader archetypes and avoiding unicorn roles
quotes.text: That's kind of the way in which I would architect it and think about it, is what's most imminent, and what do you actually need to hire for today, as opposed to just hiring for the sake of hiring and bringing in that leader.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A prioritization heuristic: hire for the most imminent need instead of prematurely hiring a broad “leader” role.

quotes.topic_title: Titles: Head of Product vs VP vs CPO
quotes.text: A lot of startups at this point are almost allergic to C titles or VP titles or are just more title agnostic than I've seen in the past, so you see a lot more of these head ofs, and that is sector leaders, up until probably C plus or D stage. And then you get to D and E, and you'll see more of the VP, director, CPO type.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A stage-based heuristic for when “Head of” vs VP/C-level titles tend to show up, useful for founders designing early org charts and job titles.

quotes.topic_title: Titles: Head of Product vs VP vs CPO
quotes.text: And I think that is the way that people should be thinking about it is, if I'm joining a company very, very early days and it's called head of engineering, that is intended to be the most senior engineering leader within the organization.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Clarifies that “Head of” can still mean top functional leader in early-stage companies, reducing title anxiety for candidates and founders.

quotes.topic_title: Titles: Head of Product vs VP vs CPO
quotes.text: The fact of the matter though is there's good reason sometimes why they're not throwing out that C title, and could this person be layered down the road? Potentially, because maybe the talent they need right now is different than, just as we had spoken to earlier, is different than the talent that they might need from a massive CPO in two and a half years.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A practical rationale for avoiding C-level titles early: the role’s required skill set can change, and future layering may be necessary.

quotes.topic_title: Titles: Head of Product vs VP vs CPO
quotes.text: Because the last thing you want to do is have to demote someone.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A memorable warning that encourages founders to choose titles that preserve flexibility as the company scales.

quotes.topic_title: Titles: Head of Product vs VP vs CPO
quotes.text: So, I guess a long-winded way of me saying there's different breadth and depth to each role, but I think for the most part, unless it's a very siloed company with multiple different VPs, if you're coming into a company and they say this is the head of product, the VP of product, or the CPO, that all means the same thing dependent on the stage, for the most part.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing: in many startups, these titles are effectively interchangeable and should be interpreted through company stage rather than prestige.

quotes.topic_title: Planting seeds early: market pulse and advisory chats
quotes.text: Regardless of whether or not you're hiring, you should always be keeping a pulse on the market. That is the most important thing.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A simple operating principle: treat market awareness as an always-on habit, not something you start when a req opens.

quotes.topic_title: Planting seeds early: market pulse and advisory chats
quotes.text: Like, you never want to put yourself in a position where you have no idea what good looks like, whether that's from a company standpoint or from a candidate standpoint.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A practical mental model for hiring readiness: continuously calibrate your definition of “good” before you need it.

quotes.topic_title: Planting seeds early: market pulse and advisory chats
quotes.text: Oftentimes, I encourage founders to simply chat with what good looks like and get a really good sense of what benchmark candidate profiles could be, and who knows where that person will be in a year or what have you, but staying really, really close to really great people and using them from an advising capacity or getting them ingrained in some type of involvement in the product prior to actually having that specific need, I think, is really important.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A seed-planting methodology: benchmark early, build relationships, and involve future hires as advisors before the role exists.

quotes.topic_title: Planting seeds early: market pulse and advisory chats
quotes.text: And by simply saying, "No agenda, I'm not trying to hire you tomorrow, I just want to know great people."
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A concrete script founders can use to start high-signal conversations without making them feel transactional.

quotes.topic_title: Planting seeds early: market pulse and advisory chats
quotes.text: When I was on the executive recruiting side of things at Daversa, the VP of engineering candidate that we ultimately landed, it was a seven month game of courtship, and let's bring him in to help out from an advising capacity, let's ask him how he would think about structuring this organization, let's talk to him about the best talent that he would recommend that we're spending time with.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A specific example showing the “long-game” approach: advisory involvement and collaboration can convert into a hire over months.

quotes.topic_title: Time investment and high-leverage sourcing tactics
quotes.text: It's more of just put yourself in the room with great people.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Reframes hiring speed as a function of proximity to high-quality people rather than a fixed timeline.

quotes.topic_title: Time investment and high-leverage sourcing tactics
quotes.text: If you are in an actual search, then you should devote all of your time to it. I know that sucks to hear, but you should be really carving out concrete time.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Sets an uncompromising expectation for founder time allocation when a key exec hire is active.

quotes.topic_title: Time investment and high-leverage sourcing tactics
quotes.text: you could spend one hour on something or you could spend 10 hours on it, but it's more so around, are you doing things to be impactful during that period of time? Are you actually doing things that are going to move the needle? Are you just blindly reaching out to people on LinkedIn? Because that's not going to be the way in which you're going to find the best of the best. Some of the greatest talent, they're not even on LinkedIn.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A leverage-based mental model for sourcing that challenges the default “more hours + more LinkedIn” approach.

quotes.topic_title: Time investment and high-leverage sourcing tactics
quotes.text: it's building a really strong network in advance, and then once you actually get to a place where you need to hire that person, calling all of those amazing people that you've built relationships with and saying, "Now tell me who your favorite person is and who the best person you've ever worked with is, and could you put me on a thread with them?"
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, repeatable tactic for warm-intro sourcing via trusted operators.

quotes.topic_title: Time investment and high-leverage sourcing tactics
quotes.text: if you are going to look for a key executive and are on a time crunch, I don't necessarily think the best use of your time is blindly reaching out to executives when you don't necessarily have the expertise in knowing which companies were thriving during that period of time, which organizations were great, and which were a little bit weaker within companies.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Warns founders that cold outreach can be inefficient without the market context to target the right orgs and teams.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite placement story and what great looks like
quotes.text: I've placed probably 85 executives over the course of my career, and then lots of entry level employees when I was in house, and also some great key leaders.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A concrete data point establishing her volume of reps and pattern recognition from many hires across levels.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite placement story and what great looks like
quotes.text: Favorite placement of all time has got to be the VP of engineering that I placed at IRL, which is, to be completely honest, a big reason that I joined that company.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Highlights a high-conviction bar for “great” talent—strong enough to influence the recruiter’s own career decision.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite placement story and what great looks like
quotes.text: Alex Strand is his name, and he is just the most incredible, atypical, high emotional intelligent engineering leader. Still super technical, but has managed teams in the hundreds, built out Amazon Prime Day, then went on to build the core messaging platform at Snapchat, called him and he was like, "Why would I ever leave? There's a ton of financial incentive and a team that I've built that all loves me."
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A specific example of what “great” looks like: rare hybrid of deep technical ability plus high EQ, with evidence from scaled, high-impact systems.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite placement story and what great looks like
quotes.text: And we got him to ultimately make a move in two weeks, which is just kind of unheard of, although it ended up being like a seven month push for a start date,
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive recruiting lesson: a fast close can still require a long, trust-heavy runway to actually land the leader.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite placement story and what great looks like
quotes.text: you close searches and you cross your fingers and hope for the best and feel very good about it, but he was one where I had all the confidence in the world that I could not have done better.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A practical quality bar: the best hires feel qualitatively different—high certainty versus the usual “hope for the best.”

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold. If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights SOC 2 as a gating requirement for enterprise sales, framing compliance as a growth lever rather than a checkbox.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
quotes.text: Beginning a SOC 2 report can be a huge burden, especially for startups. It's time consuming, tedious, and expensive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Calls out the practical cost of SOC 2, helping teams anticipate and plan for the operational load early.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
quotes.text: Over 3,000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption and efficiency data point that quantifies the potential impact of automation on compliance work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a specific time-to-audit improvement benchmark teams can use when evaluating compliance tooling and timelines.

quotes.topic_title: PM career strategy: breadth, market awareness, and moves
quotes.text: I think breadth is incredibly important. It's so critical, especially if someone has an end goal of wanting to step into a product leadership role to have been able to have touched lots of different components, as opposed to specializing in one specific thing.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A clear career strategy: optimize for breadth across product areas if you want to grow into product leadership.

quotes.topic_title: PM career strategy: breadth, market awareness, and moves
quotes.text: It's just so important that you always know the companies that are doing great things and keep those windows open for people, because you never know what the next 12 months hold, and you want to be in a position where you're never running out the door looking for what's next, but rather being able to be super selective about the things that you have in front of you.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A practical mental model: maintain ongoing market awareness so you can choose opportunities from a position of strength, not urgency.

quotes.topic_title: PM career strategy: breadth, market awareness, and moves
quotes.text: logo collecting is never something that you want to be known for, and the first thing you're taught, like entry level recruiting 101 is recognize patterns of candidates that jump from place to place and don't give opportunities a full chance.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A recruiter’s lens on job-hopping: frequent moves can create a negative pattern signal regardless of brand names.

quotes.topic_title: PM career strategy: breadth, market awareness, and moves
quotes.text: We're always looking to see where people moved the needle, especially on the product side, where their fingerprints were, what they can actually point to that they did and are proud of during their time there. And so if all that they can say that they did was onboarded and moved on, then doesn't matter where you were, but it's not going to be something that I can at least stand on to cheer you on.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: A concrete evaluation rubric: impact and identifiable ownership matter more than company logos or tenure alone.

quotes.topic_title: PM career strategy: breadth, market awareness, and moves
quotes.text: All the time. Yup. Whether you are exploratory, opportunistic, not looking at all, people are constantly calling each other, and the world of tech is so, so, so small, and no matter how fired up you were leaving a company or what went sideways, it is so critical that you try to leave the place better than you found it and do so as seamlessly as possible, because you want people to have nothing but positive to say.
quotes.speaker: Lauren Ipsen
quotes.context: Actionable reminder about references and reputation: assume backchannel checks are continuous and optimize your exits accordingly.
